comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: He's used a faster shutter speed than the other lads. He has a few people in his picture.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Seems to be some sort of voodoo effect as well. All those cracks in the plate have made that hotel fall down: maps.google.ie/?ll=53.713574,-6.349218&spn=0.003645,0...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Worth comparing with this later photo from the early 20C [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/8231168267/]

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Isn't it great to see the old symbols of trade, the Pawnbrokers three globes, the barbers red and white pole etc.  Simple and effective advertising though everybody could see you when you went in to pawn the Sunday suit:-))

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] The yoke in the street looks a bit like one on the quays in this image.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Yes, it's the Whitworth monument, moved to the quays in 1894.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Thanks, and it was erected in 1876 so that gives a time bracket of 1876 to 1883 (the latest date for the Stereoscopic Collection) I wonder would there have been a particular event in that period which would have attracted both photographers to the town on the same date?

comment.author: 60812213@N04
comment._content: I believe a symbol was used for trading as a lot of people just could not read.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] There seems to be a crowd forming at the monument, but maybe it was just a popular hanging about spot.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Curtis, pawnbrokers, in the 1901 census.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I see that the head of the family, James Curtis, was the Borough Treasurer. News of his elevation to this position on 21st June 1884, at the expense of his "popular" neighbour, Michael Finegan, made it to The Irish Canadian newspaper. He had previously been a Town Councillor.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] I read the Irish Canadian article a little differently: I think Mr. Curtis was made Borough Treasurer leaving a vacancy for a town councillor, and Mr. Finegan won the council election.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Sorry, you're right - my mistake. On the Cobra - this is the only old brand I can find but I don't think they started manufacturing until 1889 or so. and by the same company www.blancoandbull.com/boot-cleaning/cobra-boot-polish/

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: James Curtis TC of Drogheda subscribed £1 to the Artane Industrial Schools in 1876, but James Curtis, Esq, Drogheda gave only 10s to the Mansion House fund for the relief of distress in the south and west of Ireland in 1898. Jas Curtis, Drogheda (the son?) finished 3rd in the 100 yards open handicap at Oldcastle sports in 1898

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In 1837, there were two Curtis households up the hill on Peter Street: Curtis James, Peter-street, 20, House Curtis Thomas, Peter-street, 15, House

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Is this 'long-lost 'Frank from the 1901 census? London Times personal column, June 18 1940

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: It seems the Whitworth Monument was found sometime around 2005/6 and plans are/were afoot to rebuild it. homepage.eircom.net/~thewhitworth/committee.html

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Here's another more recent shot of what was Webster's bakery (thanks to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/archiseek/] for the link). The building was in the Dutch Billy style. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gentlemanofletters/3384374875/]
